instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: for testing purposes: board of 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> in 15" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> gives it picture?
threads.message:
I've a nice case and LCD of a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> which contains a completely damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board (some broken ways and copper pads becomes loose when trying to solder).
I like to check if his LCD is still fully functional.

When I connect the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board of my <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (see previous topic) on the LCD of the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, will this give me a picture?
T-Con connector to motherboard seems to be the same. Just the desired backlight voltage of the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> seems to be a little amount higher. I think I can't destroy anything?
Someone already tried this?

thanks!

threads.title: for testing purposes: board of 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> in 15" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> gives it picture?
threads.message: You should get image, that screen can be used for test.

threads.title: for testing purposes: board of 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> in 15" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> gives it picture?
threads.message:
Thanks, this gave me a clear Apple logo, so this screen should be OK.

When I open the screen further as 90Â°, I can see the flatcables becomes tight. Although it's not happened already, this is still a "flexgate" screen.
I will search for a good, or repairable board for the Macbook
But is there a known good workaround to prevent flexgate with this screen?
